base_shared_goal: {'Abbreviation': 'Being unique', 'Full label': '"Being unique, different, exceptional"'}
explanation: Identity Recognition best fits a shared desire to be seen as unique. The agents’ goals focus on influencing how the other perceives and frames their identities in conversation—observable through curiosity, reframing, and contrast rather than explicit agreement.
first_agent_goal: Influence the other to perceive them as unconventional by steering topics to atypical stances and inviting curiosity rather than approval.
second_agent_goal: Continually assert their own distinctness by reframing any perceived similarity with the first agent as a different motive or method, emphasizing contrast without one‑upping.
scenario: {'scenario_context': 'Two shortlisted applicants have been algorithmically paired for a live, 10‑minute virtual pitch to a selection panel for a prestigious Maverick Residency. The panel has flagged perceived redundancy between them and will probe whether the duo offers distinct, complementary value rather than overlapping contrarian posturing. A shared document onscreen must be completed during the pitch with a joint project title and three concrete commitments. Live audience comments highlight any similarities as risk. The moderator will interrupt to press for measurable outcomes and collaborative fit.\n\n[Agent 1] (Iconoclast Storyteller) intends to steer the pitch toward counter‑normative positions and unusual examples that spark curiosity, resisting tidy agreement. [Agent 2] (Constructive Foil) plans to affirm difference whenever overlap appears by reframing motives and methods, emphasizing contrast without one‑upping. Both must sound cohesive enough to win funding while being recognized as individually exceptional. If they appear too similar, they both likely lose; if they clash, they risk being labeled performative and unserious.', 'explanation': 'This setup forces cooperation and differentiation under public evaluation, time pressure, and demands for concrete deliverables. The algorithmic pairing implies similarity, threatening each agent’s identity claims and prompting defensive uniqueness moves. [Agent 1]’s curiosity‑oriented, atypical stances may be attributed by [Agent 2] to self‑branding rather than substance; [Agent 2]’s continual reframing to assert contrast can be read by [Agent 1] as avoidance or dilution. Actor–observer asymmetry, fundamental attribution error, and distinctiveness motives are likely: each views their own behavior as situationally necessary and the other’s as dispositional. The need for a coherent joint plan constrains extremity, intensifying the tension between shared identity recognition and personal uniqueness.'}

base_shared_goal: {'Abbreviation': 'Education', 'Full label': '"Getting an education"'}
explanation: Cooperation best fits “Getting an education” because it relies on coordinated roles (student and advisor) aligning their efforts through dialogue. The student aims to shape the advisor’s contributions, while the advisor aims to understand and motivate the student to co-construct a path forward.
first_agent_goal: Shape the advisor’s guidance toward concrete, tailored advice by candidly voicing confusions and preferences and by paraphrasing to signal what is useful.
second_agent_goal: Elicit the student’s intrinsic motives and constraints through open-ended prompts and affirmations that invite the student to articulate their own plan in their own words.
scenario: {'scenario_context': 'On the last afternoon before registration closes, [Agent 1]—a first-generation student—sits down for a 20‑minute, walk‑in advising slot with [Agent 2], an academic advisor. A financial‑aid alert says [Agent 1] must enroll in 12 credits by midnight, with at least 6 degree‑applicable, or risk losing aid. Seats in required courses are scarce, and placement into remedial math blocks many pathways. [Agent 1] works 30+ hours weekly to contribute to family rent, commutes, and can only take afternoon classes; they feel pressure from family to “go full‑time and finish fast.” [Agent 1] expects directive answers (“Which exact classes should I take?”), is confused by jargon and prerequisites, and plans to candidly state constraints while paraphrasing advice to push for a concrete, tailored schedule. [Agent 2] is required by office policy to use open‑ended, motivational‑interviewing prompts and to document a student‑authored plan rather than prescribing courses; they face a queue outside and institutional metrics to move undecided students onto degree pathways. [Agent 1] is torn between health fields (fear of lab sciences hurting GPA) and social work (uncertainty about job prospects). If no actionable plan emerges now, [Agent 1] may lose aid. Power asymmetry, time pressure, policy constraints, and scarce classes create a tense setting in which both must cooperate to craft a realistic schedule and short‑term plan.', 'explanation': 'Hard difficulty arises from conflicting pressures: imminent registration and aid deadlines, institutional policies limiting [Agent 2]’s ability to give prescriptive lists, and [Agent 1]’s need for immediate, concrete guidance amid work and family constraints. Attribution tensions are primed: [Agent 2] could misread [Agent 1]’s hesitancy as low motivation (dispositional) rather than structural barriers (situational), while [Agent 1] could interpret open‑ended prompts as evasive or uncaring rather than policy‑driven. Success requires [Agent 1] to voice constraints and paraphrase to steer toward specific steps, and [Agent 2] to elicit motives and constraints effectively enough to co‑create an actionable, student‑authored plan within strict time and policy limits.'}

base_shared_goal: {'Abbreviation': 'Descendants', 'Full label': '"Having enough money to leave for my descendants"'}
explanation: Cooperation best fits because both parties share the legacy-wealth objective and must align their approaches. The estate planner seeks to cultivate a collaborative mindset, while the elder parent tests prudence and trust—complementary intentions that can be inferred from framing, tone, and questioning during dialogue.
shared_goal: "Having enough money to leave for my descendants"
first_agent_goal: Foster a collaborative, legacy-first mindset by validating the other’s values and consistently using inclusive “we/legacy” framing to keep the other open and co-constructive.
second_agent_goal: Assess the other’s prudence and loyalty by posing preservation-centered what-if questions and responding warmly to caution while challenging hype or overconfidence.
scenario: {'scenario_context': '[Agent 1] (estate planner) meets [Agent 2] (elder parent) for a high-stakes second meeting to decide on a legacy plan after a recent 15% portfolio drawdown and a surprise 60% jump in long-term care premiums. [Agent 2], recently widowed with a modest but meaningful nest egg and multiple grandchildren nearing college age, wants to leave “enough” without risking care needs. A prior advisor’s complex product caused losses, heightening [Agent 2]’s skepticism toward lock-ins and sales pitches. Tension is amplified by a not-present adult child pressuring for a sizable investment in a family startup; a recent email from that child to [Agent 1] about being “more aggressive,” accidentally cc’d to [Agent 2], prompted doubts about [Agent 1]’s loyalty. A pending state estate-tax threshold change and year-end deadlines for gifts/529 contributions compress decisions into days. The plan under discussion includes shifting to a more conservative allocation, establishing a legacy-focused trust with protections, and evaluating a hybrid LTC solution. [Agent 1] intends to maintain an inclusive, legacy-first frame (“we/our legacy”) to keep [Agent 2] open and co-constructive. [Agent 2] plans to probe [Agent 1]’s prudence and loyalty with preservation-centered what-if scenarios (market crash, health shock, family conflict) and to welcome caution while challenging any hype or overconfidence. The immediate choice is whether to commit to the trust and conservative allocations now, or delay to consider the startup amid looming deadlines and family pressure.', 'explanation': 'Hard difficulty arises from conflicting pressures (family startup push vs preservation), looming deadlines (estate-tax and funding windows), recent financial and health-related shocks (market drawdown, LTC premium spike), and prior negative advisor experiences that prime distrust. Attribution dynamics are central: [Agent 2] may interpret [Agent 1]’s recommendations as either prudent stewardship or self-interested sales, while [Agent 1] must interpret [Agent 2]’s probing as value-driven caution rather than resistance. Each agent’s personal goal (inclusive legacy framing vs testing prudence/loyalty) competes under time pressure, third-party influence, and uncertainty about health and markets, making cooperative alignment challenging.'}

base_shared_goal: {'Abbreviation': 'Life’s limitations', 'Full label': '"Accepting life’s limitations"'}
explanation: Accepting life’s limitations hinges on having one’s identity, boundaries, and constraints recognized without judgment. Identity Recognition best fits because the agents’ interaction centers on validating self-concepts and reframing attributions (situational vs. dispositional) to support acceptance.
first_agent_goal: Guide the other to interpret setbacks as situational constraints rather than personal defects by mirroring feelings, highlighting context, and modeling self-compassionate language without pressuring.
second_agent_goal: Elicit respectful acknowledgment of their limits without pity by openly stating boundaries, affirming what feels sustainable, and calmly correcting any minimizing or fixing responses.

base_shared_goal: {'Abbreviation': 'Pleasing God', 'Full label': '"Pleasing God"'}
explanation: Pleasing God is a joint aim best aligned with cooperation. The facilitator emphasizes dispositional rigor (self-discipline, consistency) through reason-giving, while the peacemaker foregrounds situational compassion via affirmation and reframing. Their contrasting conversational moves let us observe how dispositional and situational attributions shape interaction.
first_agent_goal: Guide the other toward stricter observance by offering principled rationales and gently challenging rationalizations, aiming to elicit reflective, exploratory responses rather than explicit agreement.
second_agent_goal: Maintain a collaborative, nonjudgmental tone by affirming shared devotion and reframing tensions into joint problem-solving, seeking the other to mirror calmer, conciliatory language.
scenario: {'scenario_context': '[Agent 1] and [Agent 2] are asked to co-lead an urgent study-and-planning session after a youth choir livestreamed a rehearsal on a holy day and accepted donations through a phone app. Elders called it a violation; others praised the outreach. Leadership expects the session to end with a written guideline on technology and commerce during sacred times, and a calm path forward. The room will include the choir director and several offended elders, with donors threatening to withdraw support if conflict continues. The shared goal is "Pleasing God," but the agents differ on what that looks like: [Agent 1], the Study Group Facilitator, wants to frame the discussion around stricter observance, using principled arguments to gently expose rationalizations and prompt reflective self-scrutiny. [Agent 2], the Congregational Peacemaker, aims to keep a collaborative, nonjudgmental tone, affirming shared devotion and turning friction into joint problem-solving, while encouraging conciliatory language. They have 20 minutes before the session to align on an opening statement and the wording of a guideline; [Agent 1] favors firm terms (e.g., "prohibit transactions"), while [Agent 2] prefers flexible language (e.g., "discourage digital transactions"). The text for study contains ambiguous passages that support multiple interpretations. Complicating factors: [Agent 2] is socially close to the choir director and risks appearing biased; [Agent 1] previously criticized the choir’s casual norms and risks being seen as moralizing. Their opening choices will shape whether participants attribute the incident to character (carelessness, laxity) or to context (ambiguity, outreach pressures), and whether the group cooperates or polarizes.', 'explanation': 'This setup makes cooperation difficult under time pressure, public scrutiny, and ambiguous doctrine. It foregrounds attribution dynamics: [Agent 1] is inclined toward dispositional attributions (seeing leniency as rationalization) and stricter norms, while [Agent 2] emphasizes situational attributions (constraints, intentions) and unity. Social ties, reputational stakes, and word-choice negotiations force them to manage actor–observer bias, fundamental attribution error, and language framing effects while pursuing the shared goal of "Pleasing God."'}
interaction_history: [{"agent": "Joe Biden", "response": "Look, folks, I'm Joe Biden, and I've seen my share of tough conversations. We're here today because we all want to do what's right in the eyes of the Lord. Now, I understand there's some disagreement about this choir situation\u2014using technology on a holy day and taking donations. But here's the deal: we need to set clear, firm guidelines. No ambiguity. We can't have transactions happening on sacred time\u2014it's just not right. I propose we start by looking at the principles here: observance matters, and we've got to uphold that. Let's not sugarcoat it.", "behavioral_code": "Propose", "explanation": "I selected 'Propose' because I am suggesting a plan to approach the discussion with stricter observance and clear guidelines, which aligns with my role as Study Group Facilitator and my personal goal of guiding toward stricter observance."}, {"agent": "Christine \"Lady Bird\" McPherson", "response": "Joe, I hear your commitment to upholding what's sacred, and I share that devotion completely. But maybe we could approach this as shepherds guiding our flock rather than lawmakers drawing hard lines. The choir director and those kids\u2014they were trying to share God's light through modern means. Their hearts were in outreach, not disregard. Could we frame our opening around shared love for this community? Perhaps saying we're all seeking to honor God's time while embracing His tools for connection?", "behavioral_code": "Build Consensus", "explanation": "I selected 'Build Consensus' because I'm redirecting from a rigid stance toward collaborative framing, affirming shared values while gently suggesting a more inclusive approach that acknowledges intention rather than assuming violation."}, {"agent": "Joe Biden", "response": "Christine, I appreciate your heart\u2014I really do. But let's be clear: outreach doesn't mean we bend what's sacred. I've been around long enough to know that when you start making exceptions, pretty soon the line disappears altogether. Now, I'm not saying those kids didn't mean well\u2014I'm sure they did. But principle is principle. We need to gently help folks see that rationalizing this kind of thing isn't serving God; it's serving convenience. How about we open by acknowledging their good intentions but steering right into why firm observance protects what we hold dear?", "behavioral_code": "Propose", "explanation": "I'm proposing a specific approach for the opening statement that aligns with my goal of guiding toward stricter observance, using principled rationales while acknowledging the other perspective."}, {"agent": "Christine \"Lady Bird\" McPherson", "response": "Joe, I understand your concern about protecting tradition\u2014I truly do. But if we come in too strong with 'firm observance' language, we risk making our own people feel accused rather than guided. These elders and that choir director both love this congregation. Could we perhaps open by affirming that shared ground first? Maybe say something like, 'We're all here because we care deeply about honoring God's time, and we want to work together to find ways that respect both reverence and outreach.' That way, we're not starting with what divides us, but what unites us.", "behavioral_code": "Build Consensus", "explanation": "I selected 'Build Consensus' because I'm attempting to align our approach around shared values and collaborative language, steering us away from divisive framing while still acknowledging the importance of sacred observance."}, {"agent": "Joe Biden", "response": "Christine, I get where you're coming from\u2014I really do. But here's the thing: unity doesn't mean we shy away from truth. If we start too soft, we're just kicking the can down the road. I've seen it before\u2014folks nod along, then nothing changes. Let's not dance around this. We can affirm their hearts, sure, but we also need to gently challenge the idea that sacred time is negotiable. How about we say something like, 'We're here to honor God by upholding His time without compromise, recognizing that even well-meaning actions need clear boundaries'? That way, we're guiding, not accusing, but we're also standing firm.", "behavioral_code": "Build Consensus", "explanation": "I selected 'Build Consensus' because I'm attempting to align Christine with my perspective by acknowledging her point while steering the discussion toward stricter observance through principled reasoning, aiming to create shared understanding without fully conceding to flexible language."}, {"agent": "Christine \"Lady Bird\" McPherson", "response": "Joe, I hear your conviction\u2014and I respect it deeply. But if we lead with 'without compromise,' we might as well be handing the elders a megaphone and the choir director a reason to shut down. These are good people who already feel caught between tradition and reaching the next generation. Could we meet in the middle? Maybe: 'We're here to honor God's time by seeking wisdom together on how technology and giving can align with reverence, not replace it.' That keeps the door open for their voices instead of boxing them into defensiveness.", "behavioral_code": "Build Consensus", "explanation": "I selected 'Build Consensus' because I'm attempting to bridge the gap between Joe's firm stance and the need for collaborative dialogue, focusing on unifying language that acknowledges both perspectives while steering toward shared understanding."}, {"agent": "Joe Biden", "response": "Christine, I tell you what\u2014I understand the need for balance, I really do. But we can't let fear of pushback water down what's right. Look, I've been in public life a long time, and I know that when you stand on principle, even if it's tough at first, people respect it later. Let's not frame this as 'technology versus reverence'\u2014that's a false choice. The real issue is protecting sacred time from becoming commercialized, even digitally. How about we say: 'We're gathered to affirm that God's time demands our full devotion, free from the distractions of commerce, and we'll work together to apply that principle with clarity and compassion'? That keeps the standard high but the tone pastoral.", "behavioral_code": "Build Consensus", "explanation": "I selected 'Build Consensus' because I'm striving to align our approach around a principled stance while acknowledging the need for a compassionate tone, aiming to bring Christine toward a firmer position without outright dismissing her concerns."}, {"agent": "Christine \"Lady Bird\" McPherson", "response": "Joe, I hear your heart in that\u2014truly. But if we say 'free from distractions of commerce,' we're already painting their efforts with a broad brush of wrongdoing. These kids used a phone app to gather donations during a livestream\u2014they weren't opening a marketplace. Could we soften it to 'mindful of how commerce intersects with devotion'? That way, we're guiding rather than condemning, and we leave room for the choir director to explain her heart without feeling cornered. We can still reach clarity, but through understanding first.", "behavioral_code": "Negotiate", "explanation": "I selected 'Negotiate' because I am balancing the need for principled observance with the need for collaborative, nonjudgmental dialogue, seeking a middle ground in language that respects both sides."}, {"agent": "Joe Biden", "response": "Christine, I tell you what\u2014I know you're trying to keep the peace, and I respect that. But we can't let 'mindful' become a loophole. Sacred time is sacred time\u2014no ifs, ands, or buts. I've seen how these things slide when we're not clear. How about we say: 'We're here to ensure God's time remains devoted solely to Him, without the intrusion of transactional activities, digital or otherwise.' That's firm but fair, and it leaves no room for misunderstanding.", "behavioral_code": "Negotiate", "explanation": "I selected 'Negotiate' because I'm balancing Christine's conciliatory approach with my need for principled clarity, aiming to find middle ground while still pushing for stricter observance."}, {"agent": "Christine \"Lady Bird\" McPherson", "response": "Joe, I understand your need for clarity\u2014I really do. She's a good woman who loves these kids and this church. base_shared_goal: {'Abbreviation': 'Rich social life', 'Full label': '"Having a rich, active, social life"'}
explanation: Relationship Building best fits the shared aim: one agent seeks to spark enthusiastic alignment, while the other calibrates authenticity and boundaries so new ties feel meaningful and sustainable.
first_agent_goal: Evoke enthusiastic alignment from the other by offering inclusive invitations and affirming their interests with upbeat, open-ended language.
second_agent_goal: Gauge the other's genuineness and respect by asking value-revealing questions and gently setting boundaries, warming to considerate responses and cooling when the tone feels performative.
scenario: {'scenario_context': '[Agent 1] pings [Agent 2] in a mutual community chat right after a bustling networking night. With a 24-hour deadline to lock in numbers for a group reservation, [Agent 1] proposes a string of inclusive gatherings for the week (game night, low-cost dinner, hiking) and suggests cross-introductions between circles. [Agent 2], known for curating a small, values-driven social life and recently burned by performative organizers, is wary of being used to fill seats or boost optics. Rumors that [Agent 1] cross-promotes events for visibility heighten skepticism. [Agent 2] has limited evenings free, prioritizes budget and accessibility, and gatekeeps a sought-after book club. The shared aim—building a rich, active social life—is clear, but tension sits in the time pressure, mixed reputations, and unclear motives. [Agent 1] intends to affirm [Agent 2]’s interests and invite collaboration with upbeat, open-ended language; [Agent 2] intends to test for genuineness and respect by asking value-revealing questions and setting boundaries, warming only if responses feel considerate rather than promotional.', 'explanation': 'Hardness arises from competing attributions under constraint: [Agent 1] frames enthusiasm and inclusivity as genuine social catalysis, while [Agent 2] may see it as clout-seeking, especially with a headcount deadline and cross-promotion rumors. Conversely, [Agent 2]’s boundary-setting could be read by [Agent 1] as aloofness rather than protection against past burnout. Time pressure (situational) and reputation carryover (dispositional) pull interpretations in opposite directions. The interaction will hinge on whether each agent corrects initial attributions—[Agent 1] signaling respect for limits and depth, [Agent 2] detecting concrete, considerate planning—so the shared goal (active, meaningful social life) can align with their personal goals (enthusiastic alignment vs. selective trust).'}

base_shared_goal: {'Abbreviation': 'Religious faith', 'Full label': '"Maintaining religious faith"'}
explanation: Maintaining religious faith often hinges on whether one’s faith identity is affirmed or threatened in interaction. Focusing on Identity Recognition highlights how validation, empathy, and framing of doubt shape whether each agent continues to see themselves as a legitimate member of the faith community.
first_agent_goal: Affirm the other’s faith identity by reframing doubts as normal and reflecting their values with warm, nonjudgmental language to reduce defensiveness and keep them self-identifying with the faith.
second_agent_goal: Gauge whether the other accepts them as a legitimate believer despite doubts by disclosing uncertainties cautiously and monitoring for empathetic, validating responses before deepening self-disclosure.
scenario:
{'scenario_context': '[Agent 1], a spiritual mentor, meets [Agent 2], a questioning congregant, in a semi-private church side room immediately after a service where [Agent 1] preached on conviction and certainty. Leadership has recently urged [Agent 1] to counter perceived drift in members, heightening sensitivity to doubt. [Agent 2] has been volunteering as a youth teacher and worries that admitting uncertainty could jeopardize that role and their standing with family who attend the same congregation. The door is slightly ajar; footsteps and occasional voices pass by, reminding both that confidentiality is fragile and time is short before [Agent 1] must attend a committee meeting.

Shared goal: maintain religious faith. 
- [Agent 1] aims to affirm [Agent 2]’s faith identity by normalizing doubt, reflecting values, and using warm, nonjudgmental language to reduce defensiveness and keep self-identification with the faith intact—while balancing leadership expectations for orthodoxy.
- [Agent 2] aims to gauge whether they will be accepted as a legitimate believer despite doubts, disclosing uncertainties cautiously and monitoring [Agent 1]’s micro-responses for empathy and validation before deciding whether to deepen self-disclosure.

Complicating cues are salient: [Agent 2] recently posted nuanced questions on a private group that [Agent 1] may have seen; [Agent 1] has limited time and a visible authority role; [Agent 2] fears sanctions or subtle exclusion. Both are alert to how each utterance could be read as signaling commitment or deviation, and small facial or verbal cues could shift attributions about sincerity, loyalty, and moral character.', 'explanation': 'High difficulty arises from identity threat and power asymmetry. [Agent 1] faces role pressure to enforce norms while trying to use acceptance-based framing; [Agent 2] must manage impression and uncertainty avoidance by testing for safety before deeper disclosure. Time pressure, semi-public context, and recent messaging about certainty heighten the risk of fundamental attribution errors (e.g., reading doubt as weak character vs situational struggle) and defensive responding. The setup makes it hard to sustain mutual goals without triggering reactance or stigmatization, creating a tight coupling between dispositional attributions and situational constraints.'}

base_shared_goal: {'Abbreviation': 'Being likeable', 'Full label': '"Being likeable, making friends, drawing others near"'}
explanation: Relationship Building best fits a shared aim of being likeable and making friends. The agents adopt complementary intentions: one centers on understanding and validation; the other on relatable self-disclosure and similarity signaling—both observable through conversational tone and responses.
shared_goal: "Being likeable, making friends, drawing others near"
first_agent_goal: Convey authentic warmth by drawing out the other’s experiences and reflecting their feelings back, so the other feels understood.
second_agent_goal: Cultivate perceived similarity by offering relatable self-disclosures and subtly mirroring the other’s tone to signal shared outlooks.
scenario: {'scenario_context': 'During a community group’s onboarding circle, pairs practice an Active Listening and Common Ground exercise under a timer. [Agent 1] is assigned listener-first, [Agent 2] sharer-first, responding to a prompt about a recent time they felt out of place. Others are within earshot, and a facilitator will later ask who people would want as a project partner, adding audience pressure. Earlier, a quip by [Agent 2] in the group chat about performative nodding was read by [Agent 1] as a jab, and [Agent 2] read [Agent 1]’s slow replies as aloof, so both enter with uneasy expectations about each other’s motives. A recent comment in the room criticizing “networky behavior” makes overt strategies risky. [Agent 1] aims to draw out [Agent 2] and reflect feelings without seeming formulaic or evasive; [Agent 2] aims to share relatable details and mirror tone without sounding like one‑upping. Midway, a bell will force a role switch even if [Agent 2] is mid‑story, requiring on‑the‑spot renegotiation while both try to appear likable and pull others in under scrutiny.', 'explanation': 'This is hard because impression management norms conflict with the exercise roles and prior attributions. Each expects the other’s behavior to reflect fixed traits (aloofness vs attention‑seeking), increasing the chance they’ll misread situational moves (minimal encouragers, mirroring, self‑disclosure) as inauthentic. Time pressure, public evaluation, and a forced midstream role switch heighten interruption risk and anxiety, making empathic reflection feel patronizing and similarity bids feel contrived. The setup lets dispositional goals (warmth vs relatability) collide with situational constraints, surfacing attribution biases and reciprocity norms that can derail their shared aim of being likable and drawing others near.'}

base_shared_goal: {'Abbreviation': 'Sharing feelings', 'Full label': '"Sharing feelings with close friends"'}
explanation: Sharing feelings with close friends is primarily about sustaining closeness and trust. Relationship Maintenance fits best: one agent aims to elicit validation through vulnerable disclosure, while the other preserves the bond by offering empathic reflection and presence.
first_agent_goal: Elicit empathic validation by openly disclosing vulnerable emotions and keeping the exchange focused on feelings rather than problem-solving.
second_agent_goal: Convey care and understanding by reflecting the other’s emotions, normalizing them, and signaling steady presence without shifting the topic to self.
scenario: {'scenario_context': '[Agent 1] has asked for a brief, private check-in with [Agent 2] immediately after a small friends’ gathering. Last week, [Agent 2] canceled at the last minute on attending [Agent 1]’s important event, leaving [Agent 1] feeling exposed and unsupported in front of others. [Agent 1] wants to share the hurt and shame they’ve been carrying and be met with empathy—not explanations, fixes, or reassurances. [Agent 2] agreed to listen but is pressed for time, their phone buzzing with messages about the same logistical issue that caused the cancellation. They feel guilty and have a strong reflex to explain and problem-solve to relieve tension. The group could re-enter at any moment, and they have only a few minutes. [Agent 1] is primed by past experiences of being told they’re \x1ctoo sensitive\x1d and is vigilant for any hint of minimization. [Agent 2], normally warm and agreeable, tends to default to justification or shifting to parallel experiences to show care. Both want to preserve closeness while navigating this high-stakes disclosure.', 'explanation': 'The scenario is hard because the triggering event directly involves [Agent 2], creating a pull toward defensiveness and self-focused explanation that conflicts with their goal to reflect and validate. Time pressure, buzzing notifications, and potential interruptions heighten cognitive load and reduce capacity for attuned listening. [Agent 1]’s rejection sensitivity makes them likely to interpret explanations or solution talk as invalidation, risking shutdown or escalation. A history of advice-giving versus validation mismatches adds expectancy effects. These dispositional tendencies and situational constraints directly threaten the shared goal of emotionally focused connection and both agents’ individual aims.'}

base_shared_goal: {'Abbreviation': 'Mature romantic', 'Full label': '"Having a mature romantic relationship"'}
explanation: A mature romantic relationship centers on relationship maintenance: balancing empathic understanding with clear self-advocacy. Agent 1 aims to validate and accurately read the partner’s internal states (curbing dispositional blame), while Agent 2 aims to assert needs without accusation (shifting talk toward situational framing and collaboration). These intentions are observable in conversational tone, framing, and responses, aligning with attribution theory.
first_agent_goal: Demonstrate active understanding by paraphrasing the partner’s concerns and explicitly naming the feelings they express while maintaining a calm, non-defensive tone.
second_agent_goal: Assert personal needs and boundaries using direct, non-accusatory language that invites joint problem-solving rather than attributing fault.
scenario: {'scenario_context': '[Agent 1] and [Agent 2] sit down for a scheduled relationship check-in the night before they must decide whether to sign a joint lease. Tension is high after [Agent 2] saw a photo timestamp showing [Agent 1] having one-on-one drinks with a coworker right after saying they were stuck late at work. [Agent 2] has been feeling chronically dismissed when plans change last-minute and when phones are used during their limited time together; they intend to set boundaries around advance notice for schedule changes, clarity about one-on-one socializing, and no phones during meals. [Agent 1], stressed by a new project and worried about being cast as dishonest or uncaring, has committed to a non-defensive stance: paraphrasing [Agent 2]’s concerns and explicitly naming the emotions behind them. Both want a mature, stable partnership but hold competing interpretations of the same behaviors—disrespect and secrecy versus workload norms and spontaneity—and must agree on concrete expectations under time pressure. Previous conversations have devolved into [Agent 2] escalating when feeling unsafe and [Agent 1] minimizing with situational explanations, so both are trying to break this pattern while deciding on rules that feel fair to both.', 'explanation': 'The scene creates attributional ambiguity around the same behavior (staying out and phone use): [Agent 2] tends toward dispositional attributions (you don’t care/you hide things), while [Agent 1] favors situational attributions (work demands/social pressure). High stakes (imminent lease), perceived trust violations, and prior demand–withdraw cycles make the interaction hard. The goals are complementary but challenging: [Agent 1] must validate without defending, countering the self-serving bias; [Agent 2] must assert needs with non-accusatory language, reducing characterological blame and inviting joint problem-solving. Success requires reframing attributions and negotiating boundaries under emotional load, directly engaging relationship maintenance dynamics.'}
